intro: Gilia involucrata, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant produces showy, violet to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or gravelly soils. Its foliage consists of narrow, linear leaves that help reduce water loss in its harsh habitat.
